Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Teacher Research Teams II: Expanding Pathways

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, the University of Colorado at Boulder (CU-Boulder) will partner with Front Range Community College, (FRCC, Boulder County campus). This Scholarships & Stipends Phase II project, Collaborative Research: Teacher Research Teams II: Expanding Pathways, will support up to 36 juniors/seniors/post-baccalaureate students who are majoring in mathematics, a science discipline, or engineering (or who have completed such a major), and who are preparing to teach secondary mathematics or science in a high-need district. Approximately 40% of the scholarship funds will be awarded to undergraduates who transfer to CU-Boulder from FRCC. Each Noyce Scholar will receive 1 or 2 years of scholarship support. Project activities include a Learning Assistant (LA) program, in which faculty members engage with selected undergraduates to think about how they might improve the experience and outcomes for enrolled students, and Teacher Research Team (TRT) experiences, in which prospective teachers (Noyce Scholars), experienced and novice teachers, teacher educators, and prospective teacher educators (education graduate students) discuss and plan research, practice, assessment, and curriculum.

Building on prior work, the project will (a) develop a LA program at FRCC, which will provide early teaching opportunities to two-year college STEM students; (b) expand the Noyce Scholarship program to include FRCC students who transfer to CU-Boulder; and (c) leverage the TRT experience as a mechanism for teacher preparation, novice teacher induction, and professional development of teachers. Research focused on the two-year to four-year college pathway will address the following questions: (1) To what extent does having an LA experience at FRCC increase transfer to CU-Boulder and completion of a STEM degree at CU-Boulder? What factors of the FRCC LA program influence students' decisions to transfer to and complete a STEM degree at CU-Boulder? (2) After students transfer to CU-Boulder, to what extent does participating in another LA experience or TRT lead to enrollment and completion in the CU-Teach licensure program? What factors of these experiences at CU-Boulder influence students' decisions to pursue K-12 STEM teaching?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome 1: Development of  a Learning Assistant (LA) program at Front Range Community College (FRCC)

FRCC established a Learning Assistant program in Fall 2016 in collaboration with the University of Colorado Boulder (CU Boulder). From 2016-2020, 41 FRCC students have served as LAs. Over the four years, FRCC refined its LA-supported courses to include math classes in the STEM-pathway (Pre-Calculus, Calculus 1, and Calculus II) and first-year science courses (Physics I, Chemistry I, and Biology I). In 2019, the first pollinator LA, a transfer student who served as an LA at their former two-year college while completing their STEM degree at CU Boulder, was employed. In 2020, FRCC implemented the LA Campus software, which manages faculty course proposals, student applications, and the hiring process. LA Campus is crucial to the framework of the partnership as it allows for oversight and coordination between faculty from both institutions. FRCC has sustained the LA program and LAs continued to be employed in math and science classes during the Fall 2020 semester. 

Outcome 2: Creation of an online version of the LA pedagogy course in which FRCC students CU Boulder students are jointly enrolled

CU Boulder implemented an asynchronous online version of the pedagogy course in 2016, in which FRCC LAs participated and received a certificate of completion. The pedagogy course introduces LAs to educational research, active learning, and strategies that support: (1) eliciting student ideas and helping all group members become active and engaged in the class; (2) listening and questioning; (3) building relationships; and (4) integrating learning theories with effective practices. In the 2018-2019 academic year, FRCC LAs began earning course credit and the format was revised to a synchronous online version in which LAs engage in real-time discussions and activities for 50 minutes via Zoom. Currently, FRCC and CU Boulder students continue to enroll in a modified version of the synchronous online format of the pedagogy course.

Outcome 3: Facilitate process for two-year college students to transfer to CU Boulder

Of the 41 students who have served as LAs at FRCC, we know of 13 who have transferred to CU Boulder and are in process of completing their STEM degrees. All of the transfer students who have applied for LA positions at CU Boulder have been hired. Additionally, these formerly-FRCC LAs are progressing through other LA Program pipelines, such as the new CU Education Club, LA positions within the pedagogy course, and LA Mentoring positions.

In Fall 2018, an “extraordinary” section of the LA pedagogy class through the Department of Continuing Education at CU Boulder which enabled FRCC LAs to enroll at a significantly reduced rate covered by CU Boulder. FRCC students can transfer these credits to CU-proper when they attend the university, or transfer them to other four-year institutions. In addition to directly earning CU credits, this process also establishes a CU email address and student identification for FRCC students and allows them to fully participate in the pedagogy course through CU’s learning management system, Canvas, and access to Zoom pro and an unlimited Google Suite. 

Outcome 4: Broader Impacts

The main impact was to solidify an effective partnership between our two-year and four-year institutions, with the LA Program as the central feature of that partnership. This is crucial in our efforts to create pathways for community college students to transfer to four-year institutions with goals of completing a degree in a STEM discipline and, for some, earning licensure to teach K-12 math, science, or engineering. Establishing communities of faculty and LAs that span across institutions is a key element in creating that pathway. Aspects of our partnership that are central to these communities include the use of LA Campus, utilizing CU Boulder students as pollinator LAs at FRCC, scaling the LA mentor program to include all LAs at CU Boulder and FRCC, the online pedagogy course, and joint faculty development workshops. 

By leveraging the LA Program as the nexus of our partnership, the project has also had impacts on faculty use of research-based instructional strategies at FRCC. Working with an LA provides more opportunities for groups of students to engage in the materials, and faculty are rapidly developing or adapting existing curricular materials for use in these settings. All of this should provide a better learning experience and outcomes for students in the course.  While these pedagogical approaches are aimed to benefit all students, it is especially important for students who may become teachers to experience these models in their own learning and then to help implement them as LAs. 

This is a joint award with CU’s NSF award #1557351. CU has extended their grant and will further track FRCC LA’s to gather data regarding completion of a bachelor's degree in a STEM discipline and enrollment and completion of the CU-Teach math and science teaching licensure program.
